name: helianthus-annuus
wildlife-value: It is a great late-nectar plant for butterflies including monarch's and other pollinators.  This is a larval host plant that supports Silvery Checkerspot (Chlosyne nycteis).  The Silvery Checkerspot has at least 1-2 broods in the north from June-July in the deep south and Texas, they have as many as 3-4 broods from May through September. Birds are attracted to seeds so leave standing dead flowers into the winter as natural bird feeders.  Members of the genus Helianthus support the following specialized bees: Andrena (Callandrena s.l.) accepta, Andrena (Callandrena s.l.) aliciae, Andrena (Callandrena s.l.) helianthi, Melissodes (Eumelissodes) agilis, Dieunomia (Dieunomia) heteropoda, Megachile (Sayapis) pugnata, and Paranthidium (Paranthidium) jugatorium.
edibility: Seeds are used for cooking oil, livestock feed, and as a snack food or garnish.  Petals are edible and young flower buds can be steamed like artichokes.
light: Full sun (6 or more hours of direct sunlight a day)
fruit-description: Seeds are ovoid and somewhat flattened
flower-description: Ray flowers surround the center disc flowers and can be up to 5 inches across. Rays are yellow and disc flowers are brown to yellow to orange. Blooms mid to late summer.
leaf-description: The hairy leaves are alternate but may be opposite lower on the stalk. Margins are cordate and the shape is lanceolate. They can be up to 12 inches long.
uses: Indians ground the seeds into flour and baked into cakes. They applied a poultice of crushed plants to snakebites and also used an infusion of the flowers for chest pains or pulmonary problems.  The seeds can be used to make a purple-gray dye.
